awd_titl_txt: Implementing a linguistic database for analysis of an endangered language
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern technology allows for new ways of constructing infrastructure for linguistic analysis. The essential elements that constitute the minimal scientific documentation of a language include a reference grammar, a dictionary, and transcribed narratives with translations and linguistic analysis, and this project undertakes this by developing an interactive database of an endangered language. The project builds on a database that includes records of words, stories, and songs of the last fluent speakers of the language as well as language information derived from archival records. Using newer technology, proper morphological and syntactic analysis is now possible, identifying the parts of words, the semantic contribution of each, and how they can (and cannot) be put together to make words. This is crucial for documenting this language (thereby making it available for future analysis) because most words, and all verbs, are complex, and the translations given for them are more specific and limited to the given context than is warranted by the meanings of their several parts. This research provides insights into how a language puts emphasis on what is easy or difficult or obligatory to communicate, and on how the structure of a language provides a scaffold upon which perceptions and goals are organized. This gives a window into different ways of thinking. 

The project will be invaluable to anyone examining relationships between languages in an area where many languages came into contact with each other, and also will highlight the linguistically unusual features of this language. For instance, morphemes are a challenge to identify in the language, and word formation is complex, with little formal understanding of how it works; with challenges for theories of word formation. The database will allow for the construction of new words, and the database will allow for better analysis. The lexicon will specify the constituent morphemes as well as words that are analyzable only etymologically or not at all, and the grammar will provide insight into how to construct complex verb stems as well as syntax in the familiar sense of combining words into phrases and sentences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award in the Documenting Endangered Languages program (DEL) has supported morphological analysis of Achumawi, a heritage language of the Pit River tribe in northeastern California.


The Achumawi linguistic database has been developed since 1986 using software from the Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL), beginning with DOS and Shoebox, and then on Windows migrating first to Cellar, then to Lingualinks, and then to successive releases of Fieldworks Language Explorer (FLEx). The database integrates available but hitherto scattered and inconsistent archival material with more accurate field data recorded by the Principle Investigator (PI) in 1970-74 and 1992. 


The Documenting Endangered Languages Program has supported this work for a good portion of the years since 2014, with fiscal oversight since 2016 by the Endangered Language Fund.


An especially significant finding during the 3-year grant term reported here was discovery of how word stems in most vocabulary are composed of monosyllabic roots which can also occur as separate words. This has enabled resolution of ambiguities in the data, and has made rectification and normalization of archival material sharper and more certain, with more insightful English glosses. The results reported here open the way for preparation of a descriptive grammar, followed by a dictionary and analyzed and annotated texts, future work that is supported by currently ongoing DEL funding. Complexities at the periphery of verb stems remain to be unraveled — in the right periphery a system of auxilary verbs, and in the left periphery the pronominal prefixes and a few stative and 'modal' morphemes. After that, members of the indigenous community will assume stewardship of the database, which is annually archived by the American Philosophical Society. 


Aspects of the work have been published in prior years. The database has been made available to scholars and to members of the indigenous community from the beginning. Extensive materials are posted on a project database, with monthly and less regular communication of updates to a group of linguists and indigenous language activists. During the term reported here, monthly summaries of findings and proposals have been published in this way and continue to be available. 


Engagement with the indigenous community is not new. In the years 1971-1974, while the PI was doing fieldwork, parents in the community recruited him to teach the language to their children, and to help found and fund the Eastern Shasta County Indian Community Center and organize its programs for indigenous children. During the course of the work since about 2012, a cadre of dedicated language activists has emerged in the community and have formed a nonprofit organization, the 'Indigenous Language Network' (ILN). Some of them have been employed by the project. A former employee is now completing a PhD in Linguistics and Native American Studies at U.C. Davis, with a dissertation on students' acquisition of the rather challenging phonological system of the language. The PI has assisted language activists in the ILN and officials in governing bodies of the Pit River Tribe when they have needed appropriate expressions in Achumawi for many purposes, including pedagogy,  ceremony, prayer, song, signage for public parks, and T-shirts for indigenous cultural events such as the Ancestral Run. The PI has helped them to mine the database and, where necessary, to coin new expressions using the creative capacities of the language in authentic ways. ILN workers with project support have conducted language classes for adults and for school children, and have adapted and developed creative learning methods, such as establishing household domains in which to practice language competence, building toward the entire household functioning as a language nest. The extent and sophisitication of all of these applications of the Achumawi Language Database in the community would not have been possible without the recent progress in morphological analysis reported above. 


The two communities of the federally recognized Pit River Tribe, the Achumawi and Atsugewi, have probably been contiguous for many millennia yet have maintained the distinctness of their two languages. Currently ongoing DEL funding subsequent to that reported here supports beginning a database of the Atsugewi language. The two Pit River language databases will be essential for work reconstructing the prehistory of northern California. A comparable granularity of analysis in searchable databases would enormously facilitate that project of historical reconstruction. The PI's presentation to the Society for Study of the Indigenous Languages of the Americas (SSILA) in January 2024 lays conceptual groundwork for this and identifies plausible sociolinguistic constraints. Material on Yana and Shasta are available. The PI has also helped friends in the Wintu community by creating a keyboard customization for their heritage language and initiating a language database drawing upon published grammars and dictionaries. Replicating this methodology and technical support for other heritage languages depends upon members of language communities taking it up.
